questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, at 40 weeks' gestation is admitted to the hospital in active labor. Her first pregnancy and delivery were complicated by iron deficiency anemia and pregnancy-induced hypertension. She has had no routine prenatal care during this pregnancy but was diagnosed with oligohydramnios 4 weeks ago. The remainder of her medical history is not immediately available. A 2400-g (5.4-lb) female newborn is delivered vaginally. Examination of the newborn shows a short, mildly webbed neck and low-set ears. Ocular hypertelorism along with slanted palpebral fissures are noted. A cleft palate and hypoplasia of the nails and distal phalanges are present. There is increased coarse hair on the body and face. Which of the following best explains the clinical findings found in this newborn?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is a collection of defects associated with maternal exposure to phenytoin and other hydantoins (e.g., fosphenytoin). Use of these medications interferes with folate metabolism which often induces a deficiency. Common features of fetal hydantoin syndrome include intrauterine growth restriction, craniofacial abnormalities (e.g., cleft palate, hypertelorism, slanted palpebral fissures, and low-set ears), a short neck, limb defects (phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia), and excessive hair on the body and face. Other manifestations include cardiac anomalies (e.g., ventricular septal defect), ocular defects, hypospadias, and umbilical and inguinal hernias. Treatment is largely supportive and includes surgery to fix the cleft palate in addition to special education.

Fetal hydantoin syndrome does not typically manifest with neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida), which are usually seen in other types of folate deficiency and may occur as a result of maternal use of other anticonvulsants such as carbamazepine or valproate (see “Overview of antiepileptics to avoid during pregnancy” table).

B) INCORRECT:

Fetal posterior urethral valves cause urinary tract obstruction, which can lead to oligohydramnios and subsequent Potter sequence. Although Potter sequence can also cause craniofacial abnormalities, this syndrome is not associated with phalanx/nail hypoplasia or excessive hair growth. Additionally, posterior urethral valves almost exclusively occur in male newborns, making this diagnosis unlikely.

C) INCORRECT:

Infants born to diabetic mothers are at risk for caudal regression syndrome, a condition that causes abnormalities in the caudal portion of the body. This infant's features are largely confined to the face and thorax, making caudal regression syndrome unlikely. In addition, infants born to mothers with diabetes tend to have macrosomia, not growth restriction as seen here.
Image Description:

Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:

The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.

These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

D) INCORRECT:

Maternal alcohol intake can lead to fetal alcohol spectrum disorders, which can cause intrauterine growth restriction, hypoplastic nails, and facial dysmorphisms (e.g., ocular hypertelorism). However, fetal alcohol spectrum disorders typically do not cause cleft palate or excessive hair growth, making it an unlikely cause of this infant's symptoms.

E) INCORRECT:

Monosomy of the X chromosome leads to Turner syndrome, which may cause a webbed neck and low-set ears in a female newborn. However, Turner syndrome typically does not cause cleft palate, phalanx/fingernail hypoplasia, or excessive hair growth, making it an unlikely cause of this infant's symptoms.
questions.hint: This newborn's symptoms are most likely associated with maternal folate deficiency.

questions.text: A 30-year-old woman, gravida 2, para 1, comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. During the last two weeks, she has had nausea and two episodes of nonbloody vomiting. She also reports increased urinary frequency. Her pregnancy and delivery of her first child were uncomplicated. Last year, she had two episodes of grand-mal seizure. She is sexually active with her husband and they use condoms inconsistently. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. She does not use illicit drugs. Current medications include valproic acid and a multivitamin. Her vital signs are within normal limits. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at increased risk for requiring which of the following interventions?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Cochlear implantation may be required in some cases of sensorineural hearing loss that may occur if the mother takes an ototoxic aminoglycoside (e.g., gentamicin) during pregnancy, which can damage the vestibulocochlear nerve (cranial nerve VIII). As a cochlear implant relies on a functional auditory nerve, cochlear implantation is not indicated if the cranial nerve VIII or central auditory pathway is completely nonfunctional. Valproic acid intake is not associated with an increased risk of hearing loss.

B) INCORRECT:

Kidney transplantation may become necessary in patients with end-stage renal disease (e.g., due to glomerulonephritis, toxins). Visceral malformations such as fetal renal dysplasia are rather associated with ACE inhibitors than with valproic acid use during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Respiratory support may become necessary in children with respiratory depression caused by maternal opioid use during pregnancy. This patient has no history of opioid use. While high doses of valproic acid may lead to respiratory depression in both the mother and child, valproic acid at therapeutic doses is not known for causing respiratory distress.

D) INCORRECT:

A conization procedure is used to treat early-stage cervical cancers in women. Clear cell carcinoma of the cervix and vagina is associated with diethylstilbestrol (DES)-exposure during pregnancy. The tumor typically arises in women around 20 years of age. DES use in mothers may also cause congenital Müllerian anomalies in the child. Valproic acid use during pregnancy is not associated with cancer. As the use of DES in pregnant women is mostly discontinued, the incidence of clear cell carcinoma of the cervix and vagina is declining.

E) CORRECT:

Inhibition of folate absorption in the mother due to valproic acid intake leads to an increased risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida in the embryo, which may require lower spinal surgery after birth. Valproic acid may also cause facial, cardiovascular (e.g., atrial septal defect), and skeletal abnormalities (e.g., polydactyly), as well as cognitive impairment. While other antiepileptic drugs may also have teratogenic effects (e.g., phenytoin or carbamazepine causing fetal hydantoin syndrome), valproic acid is the most teratogenic antiepileptic drug and should be avoided in women of childbearing age whenever possible (see “Overview of antiepileptics to avoid during pregnancy” table).
Image Description:

Lumbar region of a neonate

The protruding cystic lesion with concurrent hypertrichosis is consistent with open spina bifida. Subtyping requires further diagnostics.

F) INCORRECT:

Limb defects are common in thalidomide embryopathy, a condition caused by maternal thalidomide use during pregnancy, which may lead to phocomelia and/or micromelia (“flipper limbs”). While limb defects such as polydactyly may occur in children of mothers taking valproic acid during pregnancy as well, another teratogenic effect is much more likely.

G) INCORRECT:

Dental treatment may become necessary in children born to a mother with tetracycline (e.g., doxycycline) use during pregnancy. Tetracyclines (“teethracyclines”) deposit in the tooth buds, causing significant and persistent discoloration of the teeth later on (i.e., varying intensities of yellow, gray, blue, or brown). The treatment of choice is placement of veneers or crowns to cover the discolored teeth. Valproic acid does not deposit in the teeth.

H) INCORRECT:

Growth hormone (GH) is administered in some children with delayed puberty and growth (e.g., in cases of GH deficiency, idiopathic short stature, Turner syndrome). Intrauterine growth restriction may be caused by placental insufficiency (most common cause in the US), genetic abnormalities (e.g., aneuploidy), maternal hypertensive disease (e.g., preeclampsia, chronic hypertension) or substance abuse (e.g., alcohol, cigarettes, cocaine, heroin). None of these risk factors are present in this patient, and valproic acid at therapeutic doses is not associated with growth restriction.
questions.hint: Valproic acid is known to lead to inhibition of folate absorption.

questions.text: A 30-year-old primigravid woman at 14 weeks' gestation comes to the physician for her first prenatal visit. She reports some nausea and fatigue. She takes lithium for bipolar disorder and completed a course of clindamycin for bacterial vaginosis 12 weeks ago. She works as a teacher at a local school. She smoked a pack of cigarettes daily for 12 years but stopped after finding out that she was pregnant. She does not drink alcohol. Her temperature is 37.0°C (98.6°F), pulse is 80/min, and blood pressure is 125/80 mm Hg. Pelvic examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 14-week gestation. There is mild lower extremity edema bilaterally. Urinalysis is within normal limits. The patient's child is at increased risk for developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Intellectual disability in a child can be caused by a number of conditions, of which fetal alcohol syndrome is the most common. Since the syndrome is caused by maternal alcohol consumption during pregnancy and this patient does not drink alcohol, intellectual disability is unlikely to occur.

B) INCORRECT:

Ototoxicity and hearing loss are common side effects of aminoglycosides. While it has not been definitively established that maternal intake of aminoglycosides during pregnancy causes ototoxicity in the fetus, the use of aminoglycosides during pregnancy is contraindicated. Since the patient has no history of recent aminoglycoside treatment, hearing loss in the infant is not to be expected.

C) INCORRECT:

Caudal regression syndrome can occur in infants with diabetic mothers and presents with malformations of the lumbosacral spine and varying degrees of motor function impairment and paralysis. Since the mother has no history of diabetes and her current urine sample is normal (glucose levels not elevated), caudal regression syndrome can be ruled out.
Image Description:

Lower abdomen and legs of a 2.5-year-old girl of a diabetic mother with poor glycemic control during pregnancy:

The hips and lower extremities appear hypoplastic and showed no muscular activity during the clinical examination. Orthopedic deformities included knees in a flexion contracture and equinovarus feet.

These findings are consistent with caudal regression syndrome. X-ray and MRI of the spine confirmed total sacral and partial lumbar vertebrae agenesis and termination of the spinal cord at T6.

D) CORRECT:

This patient's history of lithium intake as a treatment for bipolar disorder increases the risk of Ebstein anomaly in the fetus, which causes an atrialized right ventricle, tricuspid regurgitation, and right atrial enlargement. Lithium is thought to prevent physiological cardiac septation, leading to incomplete separation of the right atrioventricular valve from the ventricular myocardium (atrialization). The defect can either manifest with in utero heart failure (hydrops fetalis on ultrasound) or postnatal cyanosis, abnormal cardiac auscultation, and heart failure.
Image Description:

In the Ebstein anomaly, the tricuspid valve is displaced into the lumen of the right ventricle, resulting in atrialization of the right ventricle. The remaining ventricle is small and hypocontractile. Because tricuspid valve regurgitation is also usually present, there is retrograde flow in the right atrium, which is dilated by the volume overload, in addition to antegrade pulmonary blood flow. Blood flows through the patent foramen ovale or (commonly associated) atrial septal defect from the right atrium to the left atrium (right-to-left shunt) and then via the left ventricle into the circulation, resulting in pronounced cyanosis. The pulmonary circulation system may also be perfused through blood from the aorta (via the ductus arteriosus).

E) INCORRECT:

Fetal hydantoin syndrome is caused by maternal intake of antiepileptics during pregnancy, especially phenytoin. This patient has no history of epilepsy or treatment with anticonvulsants.

F) INCORRECT:

Intrauterine fetal bone damage and skeletal malformations can be caused by a number of conditions during pregnancy, including maternal alcohol abuse, maternal hyperparathyroidism, treatment with tetracyclines, and infections (e.g., varicella). This patient has no history of alcohol use, recent infections, or systemic disease but is on medication that has known teratogenic effects.

G) INCORRECT:

Chorioretinitis is a symptom of several congenital TORCH infections, including neonatal herpes simplex virus infections, neonatal toxoplasmosis, congenital CMV infections, and congenital varicella infections. Since the diseases are only transmitted to the fetus following maternal infection and this patient has no history of recent illness, chorioretinitis is unlikely to occur.
questions.hint: This patient is taking lithium for bipolar disorder. Especially during the first trimester, lithium intake may influence fetal development.

questions.text: A 32-year-old primigravid woman with a history of seizures comes to the physician because she had a positive pregnancy test at home. Medications include valproic acid and a multivitamin. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. Her baby is at increased risk for requiring which of the following interventions?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Inhibition of folate absorption in the mother due to valproic acid intake leads to an increased risk of neural tube defects such as spina bifida in the embryo, which may require lower spinal surgery after birth. Valproic acid may also cause cognitive impairment, facial, cardiovascular (e.g., ASD), and skeletal abnormalities (e.g., polydactyly), meaning that it should be avoided during pregnancy. The antiepileptic drugs phenytoin and carbamazepine should also be avoided because they may cause fetal hydantoin syndrome. Teratogenesis occurs most often during the 3rd–8th embryologic week when organogenesis is occurring. Since there is no antiepileptic drug that is not teratogenic, an antiepileptic drug should be chosen that controls seizures and is tolerated well by the mother at the lowest effective dose.

B) INCORRECT:

Kidney transplantation may become necessary in patients with end-stage renal disease (e.g., due to glomerulonephritis, toxins). Visceral malformations such as fetal renal dysplasia are rather associated with ACE inhibitors than with valproic acid use during pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Respiratory support becomes necessary in patients with respiratory depression commonly occurring in maternal opioids use during pregnancy. This patient has no history of opioid intake and valproic acid at therapeutic doses is not known for causing respiratory distress.

D) INCORRECT:

Dental treatment may become necessary in children born to a mother with tetracycline (e.g., doxycycline) intake during pregnancy. Tetracyclines (“teethracyclines”) deposit in the tooth buds, causing significant and persistent discoloration of the teeth later on (i.e., varying intensities of yellow, gray, blue, or brown). The treatment of choice is placement of veneers or crowns to cover the discolored teeth. Valproic acid does not deposit in the teeth.

E) INCORRECT:

Cochlear implantation is required in some cases of sensorineural hearing loss that may occur if the mother takes an ototoxic aminoglycoside (e.g., gentamicin) during pregnancy, which can damage the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). As a cochlear implant relies on a functional auditory nerve, cochlear implantation is not indicated if the CN VIII or central auditory pathway is completely nonfunctional. Valproic acid intake is not associated with an increased risk of hearing loss.

F) INCORRECT:

Limb defects are common in thalidomide embryopathy, a condition due to maternal thalidomide use during pregnancy, which may cause phocomelia and/or micromelia (“flipper limbs”). While limb defects may occur in mothers taking valproic acid during pregnancy as well, these are usually confined to the digits. Regardless, neural tube defects are much more likely.
questions.hint: Valproic acid intake is known to inhibit folate absorption in the mother.

questions.text: A 34-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 16 weeks' gestation comes to the physician because of nausea and recurrent burning epigastric discomfort for 1 month. Her symptoms are worse after heavy meals. She does not smoke or drink alcohol. Examination shows a uterus consistent in size with a 16-week gestation. Palpation of the abdomen elicits mild epigastric tenderness. The physician prescribes her medication to alleviate her symptoms. Treatment with which of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pantoprazole and other commonly used proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are safe to use throughout pregnancy and are a preferred treatment option for dyspepsia in pregnant women.

B) CORRECT:

Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog (PGE1 analog) that can prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcer formation by increasing the production of the gastric mucus barrier and decreasing gastric acid secretion. Misoprostol is contraindicated during pregnancy because it is associated with an increased risk of abortion and congenital malformations. Besides its off-label use for cervical ripening and labor induction, misoprostol can be used in combination with a progesterone antagonist for medical abortion.

C) INCORRECT:

Magnesium hydroxide neutralizes gastric acid in the stomach and also acts as an osmotic laxative. Taken orally, a small amount of magnesium is absorbed systemically into the maternal serum and is able to cross the placenta. However, no adverse fetal side effects associated with the oral intake of magnesium hydroxide have been reported, making it safe to use during pregnancy for the treatment of dyspepsia and/or constipation.

D) INCORRECT:

Cimetidine is an H2-blocker that reduces gastric acid production. Although it crosses the placenta, no adverse fetal effects associated with the use of this drug have been reported. H2-blockers are a preferred treatment option for dyspepsia in pregnant women.

E) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate acts by forming a protective barrier over the gastric/duodenal mucosa. Only a very small portion is absorbed and sucralfate can be used to treat dyspepsia throughout pregnancy.
questions.hint: The medication that should be avoided for treatment of this patient's dyspepsia is sometimes used off label for cervix ripening and induction of labor.

questions.text: A 28-year-old primigravid woman at 8 weeks' gestation comes to the office for her first prenatal visit. She feels well, and her pregnancy has been uncomplicated. She has no history of serious illness, and her only medication is a prenatal vitamin. She does not smoke cigarettes or drink alcohol. Vaccinations are up-to-date. Temperature is 36.8°C (98.2°F), pulse is 84/min, and blood pressure is 147/94 mm Hg on both arms. Physical examination shows bilateral breast tenderness. The uterus is consistent in size with 6–8 weeks' gestation. Laboratory studies, including a complete blood count, serum electrolytes, and creatinine, are within the reference ranges. Urinalysis shows no abnormalities. Repeat blood pressure 6 hours later is 144/89 mm Hg in the right arm and 141/86 mm Hg in the left arm. Which of the following is the most appropriate pharmacotherapy?

choices.text: No pharmacotherapy is indicated at this time

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

ACE inhibitors (e.g., lisinopril) are a first-line medication for the treatment of hypertension in nonpregnant patients. During pregnancy, however, ACE inhibitors are teratogenic, possibly resulting in cardiovascular and central nervous system malformations in the first trimester and causing oligohydramnios, renal hypoplasia, and impaired cranial ossification when administered in the second and third trimesters.

B) CORRECT:

Methyldopa is a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist that is safe for use in pregnancy. Mild chronic hypertension in pregnancy is defined as blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg but < 160/90 mm Hg and should be treated with oral agents to reduce the risk of adverse pregnancy outcomes. Other oral antihypertensives indicated in pregnancy include oral nifedipine, labetalol, or hydralazine. Patients with severe hypertension (i.e., systolic blood pressure ≥ 160 mm Hg and/or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 110 mm Hg lasting ≥ 15 minutes) require urgent blood pressure control with parenteral labetalol, parenteral hydralazine, or nifedipine.

See “Overview of antihypertensives to avoid during pregnancy” table.

C) INCORRECT:

Thiazide diuretics (e.g., hydrochlorothiazide) are a first-line medication for the treatment of hypertension in nonpregnant patients. Thiazide diuretics are not associated with teratogenicity and may be used in pregnant patients with volume overload (e.g., heart failure) or if other agents fail to reduce blood pressure. They are not, however, recommended as first-line therapy during pregnancy because they decrease plasma volume, which may result in a reduction of placental perfusion.

D) INCORRECT:

Previously, pharmacotherapy was reserved for patients with severe chronic hypertension in pregnancy (i.e., blood pressure ≥ 160/110 mm Hg). However, according to recent data, the threshold to initiate antihypertensives in treatment-naive patients is a blood pressure ≥ 140/90 mm Hg. Therefore, pharmacotherapy is recommended for this patient.

E) INCORRECT:

Beta blockers (e.g., atenolol) are not a recommended first-line therapy for hypertension. During pregnancy, beta blockers are safe to use, but atenolol is contraindicated because it causes intrauterine growth restriction and impairs placental growth. Preferred beta blockers during pregnancy include labetalol and metoprolol.
questions.hint: Chronic hypertension can be diagnosed in nonpregnant patients and in pregnant patients during the first 20 weeks of pregnancy if they present with systolic blood pressure ≥ 140 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure ≥ 90 mm Hg on two separate measurements at least 4 hours apart.

questions.text: A 2-day-old female newborn is brought to the physician by her parents because she has not urinated since delivery. She was born at home at 39 weeks' gestation after an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother reports having occasional headaches during pregnancy. The parents had refused prenatal care. The patient is 43.2 cm (17 in) in length and weighs 2180 g (4 lb 13 oz). Her blood pressure is 44/26 mmHg. Examination shows a large and soft anterior fontanel. The parietal bones are palpable only over the lateral surface of the cranium. Ultrasonography of the abdomen shows bilateral renal hypoplasia. Which of the following medications did the mother most likely take during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the use of tetracyclines during pregnancy is associated with the inhibition of bone growth, malformation, and discoloration of the primary teeth, it does not cause fetal renal malformations.

B) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine intake during pregnancy can cause maternal folate deficiency, which is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, microcephaly, fingernail hypoplasia, and neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida). Carbamazepine use does not cause fetal renal malformations or hypocalvaria.

C) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can be used during the first trimester of pregnancy but should be avoided during the second and third trimesters, especially after 30 weeks' gestation. Intake of NSAIDs during this period is associated with premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and inhibition of uterine contractility. Ibuprofen intake does not cause fetal renal malformations or hypocalvaria.

D) INCORRECT:

Isotretinoin intake during pregnancy is associated with congenital malformations, such as cardiac abnormalities and facial cleft. Although isotretinoin use can cause craniofacial dysmorphism, hypocalvaria and renal hypoplasia are not expected.

E) INCORRECT:

Warfarin intake during pregnancy is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, bone deformities (e.g., nasal hypoplasia), ophthalmic abnormalities, and cerebral hemorrhage. Warfarin use does not cause renal hypoplasia or hypocalvaria.

F) CORRECT:

In utero exposure to ACE inhibitors (e.g., captopril) or angiotensin receptor blockers can cause fetal renal hypoplasia. Other harmful side effects of ACE inhibitors, when taken after the first trimester, include oligohydramnios and its complications (e.g., intrauterine growth restriction, Potter sequence), poor cranial ossification (e.g., hypocalvaria), and fetal death. ACE inhibitors are also associated with cardiovascular and CNS malformations when taken during the first trimester. Therefore, ACE inhibitors should be avoided during pregnancy. Pregnant patients with new or existing hypertension should be treated with an antihypertensive that is safe for use during pregnancy (e.g. methyldopa). Renal hypoplasia, oligohydramnios, and IUGR can already be detected during prenatal ultrasonography.

A healthy newborn must pass urine within 24 hours of birth. Other causes of fetal renal hypoplasia include environmental factors (e.g., maternal nutritional deficiencies, maternal diabetes).
questions.hint: The large fontanel and incompletely formed skull bones suggest hypocalvaria.

questions.text: A 28-year-old woman at 14 weeks’ gestation presents with fever and costovertebral angle tenderness. Which antibiotic is contraindicated in pregnancy due to fetal musculoskeletal toxicity?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Ciprofloxacin, a fluoroquinolone, inhibits bacterial topoisomerases, crucial for DNA replication. However, it also affects cartilage development, as shown in animal studies, leading to concerns about fetal musculoskeletal toxicity. This risk makes fluoroquinolones contraindicated during pregnancy, especially during critical periods of fetal musculoskeletal development.

Key learning point: Ciprofloxacin is contraindicated during pregnancy due to potential adverse effects on fetal cartilage development and risk of musculoskeletal abnormalities.

B) INCORRECT:

Azithromycin, a macrolide antibiotic, is safe for use during pregnancy and does not cause fetal musculoskeletal toxicity. This toxicity is primarily linked to fluoroquinolones, which interfere with cartilage development, unlike azithromycin.

C) INCORRECT:

Cephalexin, a first-generation cephalosporin, is considered safe during pregnancy. It inhibits bacterial cell wall synthesis without affecting fetal cartilage or bone development, and is not associated with fetal musculoskeletal toxicity.

D) INCORRECT:

Nitrofurantoin is commonly used for urinary tract infections during pregnancy, especially in the first and second trimesters. It is not associated with fetal musculoskeletal toxicity, which is a concern with tetracyclines, not nitrofurantoin.

questions.text:
A 32-year-old G2P1 woman at 23 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic with consistently elevated blood pressure readings over multiple prenatal visits. She has a 4-year history of chronic hypertension, previously treated with lisinopril until pregnancy was confirmed. Her current blood pressures average 146/92 mmHg. She denies headache, visual changes, or right upper quadrant pain. Physical examination shows normal reflexes and no peripheral edema. Fetal heart rate is 136 beats per minute. Laboratory results reveal normal serum creatinine at 70 µmol/L (reference range 45–90 µmol/L) and no proteinuria. She expresses concern about a safe and effective long-term antihypertensive regimen during her remaining weeks of pregnancy.
Which of the following medications is most appropriate for controlling her blood pressure at this time?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Methyldopa is a centrally acting antihypertensive that reduces sympathetic outflow and vascular resistance by stimulating central α2-adrenergic receptors. It has a long history of safe use in pregnancy, making it suitable for managing chronic hypertension in pregnant women. Methyldopa minimizes risks of teratogenicity and adverse fetal outcomes, unlike ACE inhibitors or angiotensin receptor blockers, which can impair fetal renal development. It is a reliable option for long-term blood pressure management during pregnancy.

Key learning point: Methyldopa is a safe and appropriate choice for managing hypertension in pregnancy, while ACE inhibitors and angiotensin receptor blockers are contraindicated due to teratogenic risks.

B) INCORRECT:

Losartan, an angiotensin receptor blocker, is contraindicated in pregnancy as it can impair fetal kidney development and decrease amniotic fluid production, leading to oligohydramnios. Its mechanism of action poses significant risks during the second and third trimesters.

C) INCORRECT:

Enalapril, an ACE inhibitor, is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its potential to disrupt the fetal renin-angiotensin system, leading to renal dysgenesis and oligohydramnios. Despite its effectiveness in non-pregnant patients, its teratogenic potential during the second trimester makes it unsuitable for this patient.

D) INCORRECT:

Hydrochlorothiazide, a thiazide diuretic, is not recommended as a first-line antihypertensive in pregnancy. It can reduce plasma volume, risking decreased uterine blood flow. Alternative agents like methyldopa, labetalol, or nifedipine are preferred due to their safety and efficacy profiles.

questions.text:
A 28-year-old G2P1 woman at 16 weeks’ gestation presents to the Outpatient Clinic for prenatal care. She has a history of chronic hypertension diagnosed four years ago, managed with an angiotensin II receptor blocker at 50 mg daily. Her prior medical records show stable disease with no cardiovascular complications. She denies any new symptoms. Fetal ultrasound is appropriate for gestational age (see lab results).

Blood pressure
145/92 mmHg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Creatinine
80 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L


Potassium
4.3 mmol/L
3.5 - 5.1 mmol/L



She asks if she should continue her current antihypertensive therapy. Which of the following is the most appropriate next step in management?

choices.text: Stop all antihypertensive therapy until third trimester
Add low-dose thiazide diuretic to current regimen
Discontinue current medication and start methyldopa
Continue current regimen and monitor closely

questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Discontinuing all antihypertensive therapy in a patient with chronic hypertension risks maternal complications like placental abruption and preeclampsia. While ARBs are contraindicated, substituting them with safer alternatives is essential to maintain blood pressure control and minimize risks to both mother and fetus.

B) INCORRECT:

Adding a thiazide diuretic does not address the contraindication of angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) in pregnancy. Thiazides can reduce plasma volume, potentially compromising placental blood flow. Safe antihypertensive options in pregnancy include methyldopa, labetalol, and nifedipine.

C) CORRECT:

Angiotensin II receptor blockers (ARBs) are contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic risks, including fetal renal development issues and oligohydramnios. Methyldopa, a centrally acting alpha-2 adrenergic agonist, is preferred for managing chronic hypertension in pregnancy. It reduces sympathetic outflow, decreasing systemic vascular resistance and controlling blood pressure without significant fetal risks. Methyldopa's safety profile and clinical use history make it a suitable choice for pregnant patients.

Key learning point: Losartan, an ARB, is contraindicated in pregnancy due to teratogenic risks, and methyldopa is a safe alternative for managing hypertension in pregnant women.

D) INCORRECT:

Continuing an angiotensin II receptor blocker (ARB) during pregnancy is inappropriate due to its teratogenic risks, including fetal renal dysgenesis and oligohydramnios. Despite maternal stability, the potential fetal harm from ARBs necessitates switching to a safer antihypertensive medication.

questions.text: You are seeing a 2-day-old female newborn who is brought to your clinic by her parents because she has not urinated since birth. She was born at home at 39 weeks' gestation following an uncomplicated spontaneous vaginal delivery. The mother reports occasional headaches during pregnancy, and the parents declined prenatal care. The newborn is 43.2 cm in length and weighs 2180 g. Her blood pressure is 44/26 mmHg. On examination, she has a large, soft anterior fontanel. The parietal bones are palpable only over the lateral surface of the cranium. Abdominal ultrasonography reveals bilateral renal hypoplasia. Which one of the following medications did the mother most likely take during pregnancy?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Although the use of tetracyclines during pregnancy is associated with the inhibition of bone growth, malformation, and discoloration of the primary teeth, it does not cause fetal renal malformations.

B) INCORRECT:

Carbamazepine intake during pregnancy can cause maternal folate deficiency, which is associated with intrauterine growth restriction, microcephaly, fingernail hypoplasia, and neural tube defects (e.g., spina bifida). Carbamazepine use does not cause fetal renal malformations or hypocalvaria.

C) INCORRECT:

Isotretinoin intake during pregnancy is associated with congenital malformations, such as cardiac abnormalities and facial cleft. Although isotretinoin use can cause craniofacial dysmorphism, hypocalvaria and renal hypoplasia are not expected.

D) CORRECT:

In utero exposure to ACE inhibitors (e.g., captopril) or angiotensin receptor blockers can cause fetal renal hypoplasia. Other harmful side effects of ACE inhibitors, when taken after the first trimester, include oligohydramnios and its complications (e.g., intrauterine growth restriction, Potter sequence), poor cranial ossification (e.g., hypocalvaria), and fetal death. ACE inhibitors are also associated with cardiovascular and CNS malformations when taken during the first trimester. Therefore, ACE inhibitors should be avoided during pregnancy. Pregnant patients with new or existing hypertension should be treated with an antihypertensive that is safe for use during pregnancy (e.g. methyldopa). Renal hypoplasia, oligohydramnios, and IUGR can already be detected during prenatal ultrasonography.

A healthy newborn must pass urine within 24 hours of birth. Other causes of fetal renal hypoplasia include environmental factors (e.g., maternal nutritional deficiencies, maternal diabetes).

Key learning point: ACE inhibitors are teratogenic in pregnancy and can cause fetal renal hypoplasia, oligohydramnios, poor cranial ossification, and increased risk of fetal death.

E) INCORRECT:

NSAIDs (e.g., ibuprofen) can be used during the first trimester of pregnancy but should be avoided during the second and third trimesters, especially after 30 weeks' gestation. Intake of NSAIDs during this period is associated with premature closure of the ductus arteriosus, persistent pulmonary hypertension, and inhibition of uterine contractility. Ibuprofen intake does not cause fetal renal malformations or hypocalvaria.
questions.hint: The large fontanel and incompletely formed skull bones suggest hypocalvaria.

questions.text: You are seeing a 34-year-old woman, gravida 3, para 2, at 16 weeks' gestation who presents with a 1-month history of nausea and recurrent burning epigastric discomfort. Her symptoms worsen after heavy meals. She does not smoke or consume alcohol. On examination, her uterus size is consistent with 16 weeks' gestation, and there is mild epigastric tenderness on abdominal palpation. You plan to prescribe medication to alleviate her symptoms. Treatment with which one of the following drugs should be avoided in this patient?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Pantoprazole and other commonly used proton pump inhibitors (PPIs) are safe to use throughout pregnancy and can be considered for dyspepsia treatment if preferred medications (e.g., calcium-containing antacids) do not provide symptom relief.

B) INCORRECT:

Sucralfate acts by forming a protective barrier over the gastric/duodenal mucosa. Only a very small portion is absorbed and sucralfate can be used to treat dyspepsia throughout pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Cimetidine is an H2-blocker that reduces gastric acid production. Although it crosses the placenta, no adverse fetal effects associated with the use of this drug have been reported. H2-blockers are a preferred treatment option for dyspepsia in pregnant women.

D) INCORRECT:

Magnesium hydroxide neutralizes gastric acid in the stomach and also acts as an osmotic laxative. Taken orally, a small amount of magnesium is absorbed systemically into the maternal serum and is able to cross the placenta. However, no adverse fetal side effects associated with the oral intake of magnesium hydroxide have been reported, making it safe to use during pregnancy for the treatment of dyspepsia and/or constipation.

E) CORRECT:

Misoprostol is a prostaglandin analog (PGE1 analog) that can prevent NSAID-induced peptic ulcer formation by increasing the production of the gastric mucus barrier and decreasing gastric acid secretion. Misoprostol is contraindicated during pregnancy because it is associated with an increased risk of abortion and congenital malformations. Besides its off-label use for cervical ripening and labor induction, misoprostol can be used in combination with a progesterone antagonist for medical abortion.

Key learning point: Misoprostol is contraindicated in pregnancy due to its risk of causing abortion and congenital malformations.
questions.hint: The medication that should be avoided for treatment of this patient's dyspepsia is sometimes used off label for cervix ripening and induction of labor.

questions.text:
An 18-year-old primigravida at 35 weeks’ gestation presents to the clinic with a severe headache, visual disturbances, and intense upper abdominal pain for the past 6 hours. She has 3+ proteinuria and normal reflexes. Fetal heart tracing is reassuring. She denies any chest pain or dyspnea. No signs of placental abruption are noted (see lab results).

Blood pressure
182/116 mm Hg



Test
Result
Normal Values



Platelet count
250 x 10⁹/L
150 - 400 x 10⁹/L


Alanine aminotransferase
30 IU/L
5 - 40 IU/L


Creatinine
79 μmol/L
44 - 115 μmol/L



Which of the following is the most appropriate medication for initial acute control of this patient’s blood pressure?
questions.solution:
A) CORRECT:

Intravenous hydralazine is a direct arteriole vasodilator used for rapid blood pressure control in severe hypertension during pregnancy, such as in severe preeclampsia. It relaxes vascular smooth muscle, decreasing systemic vascular resistance and promptly reducing blood pressure. This rapid action is crucial to prevent complications like stroke and placental abruption. Hydralazine is preferred in pregnancy as it maintains uteroplacental perfusion, minimizing fetal risk compared to other antihypertensives.

Key learning point: Hydralazine is used for acute management of severe hypertension in pregnancy, while Methyldopa is preferred for chronic hypertension management during pregnancy.

B) INCORRECT:

Oral methyldopa is used for chronic hypertension management in pregnancy due to its safety profile. However, its slow onset and oral administration make it unsuitable for acute hypertensive crises, where rapid blood pressure reduction is necessary.

C) INCORRECT:

Enalapril, an angiotensin-converting enzyme inhibitor, is contraindicated in pregnancy due to risks of fetal renal dysgenesis and oligohydramnios. It is not used for acute blood pressure control in pregnancy, especially in severe preeclampsia, due to potential fetal harm.

D) INCORRECT:

Intravenous magnesium sulfate is used in severe preeclampsia to prevent seizures by reducing neuronal excitability. It does not have significant antihypertensive effects, making it unsuitable for immediate blood pressure control in acute hypertensive emergencies.

questions.text: A 32-year-old woman comes to the physician because of fatigue, breast tenderness, increased urinary frequency, and intermittent nausea for 2 weeks. Her last menstrual period was 7 weeks ago. She has a history of a seizure disorder treated with carbamazepine. Physical examination shows no abnormalities. A urine pregnancy test is positive. The child is at greatest risk of developing which of the following complications?
questions.solution:
A) INCORRECT:

Visceral malformations such as fetal renal dysplasia are associated with the use of ACE inhibitors during pregnancy, particularly if this use occurs during the second and third trimesters. Carbamazepine use, however, is not associated with an increased risk of renal dysplasia.

B) CORRECT:

Neural tube defects, such as meningocele, are associated with carbamazepine intake during pregnancy due to maternal folate deficiency. Carbamazepine can result in maternal folate deficiency, which prevents proper closure of the neural plate in the embryo during the fourth week of pregnancy. Most commonly, the caudal end of the neural tube is affected, which results in spina bifida. Carbamazepine may also cause developmental delay, cleft palate, skeletal abnormalities (e.g., finger hypoplasia), and cardiovascular abnormalities. All women should receive folate supplementation during pregnancy, particularly when receiving a folate antagonist.

There is no antiepileptic drug that is not teratogenic. If a pregnant woman, or a woman wishing to conceive, requires antiseizure treatment, an agent should be chosen that controls seizures and is tolerated well by the mother at the lowest effective dose. Valproate, however, should generally be avoided in pregnancy.

C) INCORRECT:

Teeth discoloration is associated with tetracycline (e.g., doxycycline) intake during pregnancy. Tetracyclines deposit in the buds of developing teeth, and this can cause significant and persistent yellow-brownish discoloration of the teeth. Carbamazepine does not deposit in the teeth.

D) INCORRECT:

Sensorineural hearing loss may occur in a child whose mother took aminoglycosides (e.g., gentamicin) during pregnancy, which can damage the vestibulocochlear nerve (CN VIII). Carbamazepine use, however, is not associated with an increased risk of hearing loss.

E) INCORRECT:

Clear cell carcinoma of the cervix and vagina is associated with diethylstilbestrol (DES) intake during pregnancy. Although women exposed to DES in utero do not develop this tumor until around 20 years of age, abnormalities of the reproductive tract (e.g., uterine hypoplasia) may already be present at birth. As the use of DES in pregnant women is mostly discontinued, the incidence of clear cell carcinoma of the cervix and vagina is in decline. Carbamazepine use during pregnancy, however, is not associated with cancer.

F) INCORRECT:

Limb malformation is common in thalidomide embryopathy, a condition that is caused by maternal thalidomide use during pregnancy. It can cause phocomelia and/or micromelia. Although carbamazepine use can cause minor skeletal anomalies, such as finger hypoplasia and facial dysmorphism, limb malformations are uncommon.

G) INCORRECT:

Tricuspid valve displacement is a finding in Ebstein anomaly, which may be associated with prenatal lithium exposure. Carbamazepine use, however, is not associated with Ebstein anomaly.
questions.hint: Carbamazepine intake is known to inhibit folate absorption in pregnant women.
